subject: Re: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: Thank you. Well, most probably I was not clear. I m sorry for that. I ll try again: After testing the model, I like to do integration tests for model, control
messageBody:
Thank you. Well, most probably I was not clear. I'm sorry for that. I'll try
again:

After testing the model, I like to do integration tests for model, control
and view. I do this by checking the view. But as the view is used by users
only, there is no need to know state, at least for programm components other
than the tests. This approach is (Did I get you right now?) not favorable in
your eyes? Which would be your favorable approach?

Toyin

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 4:43 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?


>
> > Just to make sure, that I understood your point of view:
> >
> > In your opinion every viewable part of the view should be
> > made accessible by
> > some method?
> > I have, e.g., a JTextField that displays some output text.
> > Thus I would add a method to give access to the String
> > representation.
> >
> > Did I get you right?
>
> No. I am not meaning to say that. What I was saying is that need-to-know
> states should be made accessible by methods that look at inner states
> (usually as composites). Of course, this is not a silver bullet, it is
> simply one idea for testing one type of situation.
>
> -Jason
